sen.j: 従三位（じゅざんみ）は、位階及び神階における位のひとつ。
sen.e: "Jusanmi" (Junior Third Rank) is a rank in court ranks and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods).
"Jusanmi" (Junior Third Rank) is a rank in court ranks and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods).
"Jusanmi" (Junior Third Rank) is a rank in court ranks and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods).

sen.j: 正三位の下、正四位（正四位上）の上に位した、律令制下では任参議及び従三位以上の者を公卿といった。
sen.e: It ranked below Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and above Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) (Shoshiinojo (Senior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)). Under the ritsuryo system, those ranked Ninsangi and Jusanmi or higher were called kugyo (court noble).
sen.cmt: 「位した、」は「位した。」と解釈しました。任参議→Ninsangi[正しい読み方が不明です］
sen.e: It ranked below Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and above Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) (Shoshiinojo (Senior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)). Under the ritsuryo system, those ranked Ninsangi and Jusanmi or higher were called kugyo (court noble).

It ranked below Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and above Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) (Shoshiinojo (Senior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)). Under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), those ranked Ninsangi and Jusanmi or higher were called kugyo (court noble).

sen.j: 贈位の場合、贈従三位とされた。
sen.e: In case of posthumous honor, it was called Zojusanmi (posthumous Jusanmi).
In case of posthumous honor, it was called Zojusanmi (posthumous Jusanmi).
In case of posthumous honor, it was called Zojusanmi (posthumous Jusanmi).

sen.j: 従三位
sen.e: Jusanmi
Jusanmi
Jusanmi

sen.j: 律令制下においては、従三位以上を『貴』と称し、また星の位ともいわれ、上級貴族の位階であった。
sen.e: Under the ritsuryo system, Jusanmi or higher ranks were called "ki" or star ranks, and were court ranks for senior kizoku (noble).
sen.cmt: 貴→ki[正しい読み方が不明です］
sen.e: Under the ritsuryo system, Jusanmi or higher ranks were called "ki" or star ranks, and were court ranks for senior kizoku (noble).
Under the ritsuryo system, Jusanmi or higher ranks were called "ki" (literally, noble) or star ranks, and were court ranks for senior kizoku (noble).

sen.j: 勲等との対比では勲二等に比例し、正四位上参議及び従三位以上の官位にある者を公卿、上達部とした。
sen.e: When contrasted with kunto (Order of Merit), it corresponds to Kunnito (Order of Second Class), and those with Shoshiinojo Sangi (councilor) and Jusanmi or higher court ranks were considered kugyo or kandachime (court noble).

When contrasted with kunto (Order of Merit), it corresponds to Kunnito (Order of Second Class), and those with Shoshiinojo Sangi (councilor) and Jusanmi or higher court ranks were considered kugyo or kandachime (court noble).

When contrasted with kunto (Order of Merit), it corresponds to Kunnito (Order of Second Class), and those with Shoshiinojo Sangi (councilor) and Jusanmi or higher court ranks were considered kugyo or kandachime (court noble).

sen.j: 律令制下においては、正四位上参議及び従三位以上の有位者は氏の下に「朝臣」の姓を名乗り、さらに名（諱）の下に「卿」の敬称が付され、さらに大臣の任にある者への敬称は「公」とされた。
sen.e: Under the ritsuryo system, those with ranks Shoshiinojo Sangi, Jusanmi, or higher added 'Ason' under their family names and a title of honor, 'kyo,' was added under their first names (imina (real name)), while those who served as a minister were given a title of honor, 'ko.'

Under the ritsuryo system, those with ranks Shoshiinojo Sangi, Jusanmi, or higher added 'Ason' under their family names and a title of honor, 'kyo,' was added under their first names (imina (real name)), while those who served as a minister were given a title of honor, 'ko.'

Under the ritsuryo system, those with ranks Shoshiinojo Sangi, Jusanmi, or higher added 'Ason' (second highest of the eight hereditary titles) under their family names and a title of honor, 'kyo,' was added under their first names (imina (real name)), while those who served as a minister were given a title of honor, 'ko.'

sen.j: 代わりに、従四位以上で公卿でない者については、氏と諱の下に「朝臣」を名乗った。
sen.e: Instead, those who were Shoshii or higher, but not a kugyo, added 'Ason' under their family name and imina.
Instead, those who were Shoshii or higher, but not a kugyo, added 'Ason' under their family name and imina.
Instead, those who were Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) or higher, but not a kugyo, added 'Ason' under their family names and imina.

sen.j: また、三位以上の公卿が亡くなった場合、皇族同様、死去のことを薨去と称する。
sen.e: Additionally, when a kugyo ranking Sanmi or higher died, the term kokyo was used, as was the case with the imperial family, to describe their death.
Additionally, when a kugyo ranking Sanmi or higher died, the term kokyo was used, as was the case with the imperial family, to describe their death.
Additionally, when a kugyo ranking Sanmi or higher died, the term kokyo was used, as was the case with the imperial family, to describe their death.

sen.j: また、後代には「三位殿」或いは「三位様」とも称された。
sen.e: Furthermore, in later years, they were referred to as 'Sanmi-dono' or 'Sanmi-sama.'
Furthermore, in later years, they were referred to as 'Sanmi-dono' or 'Sanmi-sama.'
Furthermore, in later years, they were referred to as 'Sanmi-dono' or 'Sanmi-sama.'

sen.j: また、三位以上の者は自らの家政機関として、政所を開くことを許され、家司として職事従三位家令、少初位下職事三位家書吏とした。
sen.e: In addition, those ranking Sanmi or higher were allowed to establish a mandokoro (administrative division of a high-rank family) as an agency for the household, and had Shikiji Jusanmi Karei, Shoshoinoge Shikiji Sanmi Keshori as keishi (personnel in charge of household affairs).
sen.cmt: 家書吏→Keshori[正しい読み方が不明です］
sen.e: In addition, those ranking Sanmi or higher were allowed to establish a mandokoro (administrative division of a high-rank family) as an agency for the household, and had Shikiji Jusanmi Karei, Shoshoinoge Shikiji Sanmi Keshori as keishi (personnel in charge of household affairs).

In addition, those ranking Sanmi or higher were allowed to establish a mandokoro (administrative division of a high-rank family) as an agency for the household, and had Shikiji Jusanmi Karei (butler), Shoshoinoge Shikiji Sanmi Keshori as keishi (personnel in charge of household affairs).

sen.j: 官位相当において従三位に相当する官職としては、大宰帥、弾正尹、中納言、左右の近衛大将などがあるが、実際には太宰帥は親王が任官する例が多く、近衛大将は左大臣及び右大臣が兼官する場合が慣例化し、三位にある者は左右の近衛中将となる場合が多かった。
sen.e: In kani soto (corresponding relationship between court ranks of government officials and government posts), the corresponding government officials for Jusanmi are Dazainosochi (Chief of Dazaifu), Danjonokami (Chief of Danjo), Chunagon (Middle Counselor), left and right Konoe-Daisho (commander of the inner palace guard division), etc., but in reality, the Imperial Prince often served as the Dazainosochi, Konoe-Daisho was routinely doubled by the Sadaijin (minister of the left) and Udaijin (minister of the right), and those with Sanmi often became left or right Konoe-Chujo (lieutenant general of the inner palace guard division).

In kani soto (corresponding relationship between court ranks of government officials and government posts), the corresponding government officials for Jusanmi are Dazainosochi (Chief of Dazaifu), Danjonokami (Chief of Danjo), Chunagon (Middle Counselor), left and right Konoe-Daisho (commander of the inner palace guard division), etc., but in reality, the Imperial Prince often served as the Dazainosochi, Konoe-Daisho was routinely doubled by the Sadaijin (minister of the left) and Udaijin (minister of the right), and those with Sanmi often became left or right Konoe-Chujo (lieutenant general of the inner palace guard division).

In kani soto (corresponding relationship between court ranks of government officials and government posts), the corresponding government officials for Jusanmi are Dazai no sochi (Governor-General of the Dazai-fu offices, danjoin (President of the Board of Censors), Chunagon (Vice-councilor of state), left and right Konoe-Daisho (commander of the inner palace guard division), etc., but in reality, the Imperial Prince often served as the Dazai no sochi, Konoe-Daisho was routinely doubled by the Sadaijin (minister of the left) and Udaijin (minister of the right), and those with Sanmi often became left or right Konoe-Chujo (lieutenant general of the inner palace guard division).
sen.cmt: 大宰帥、弾正尹の訳を補足"Chunagon (Middle Counselor)"→"Chunagon (Vice-councilor of state)"に変更しました。

sen.j: 故に三位でありながら中将の任にある者を三位中将と称する。
sen.e: Therefore, those who serve as Chujo despite being Sanmi were called Sanmi-Chujo (Third Rank assistant director).
Therefore, those who serve as Chujo despite being Sanmi were called Sanmi-Chujo (Third Rank assistant director).
Therefore, those who serve as Chujo despite being Sanmi were called Sanmi-Chujo (Third Rank assistant director).

sen.j: 平安時代、平清盛が武士として初めて公卿になる以前は、清和源氏、桓武平氏とも正四位を極位とした。
sen.e: In the Heian period, until TAIRA no Kiyomori became the first samurai to become kugyo, the highest rank for both Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) and Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan) was Shoshii.
In the Heian period, until TAIRA no Kiyomori became the first samurai to become kugyo, the highest rank for both Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) and Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan) was Shoshii.
In the Heian period, until TAIRA no Kiyomori became the first samurai to become kugyo, the highest rank for both Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) and Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan) was Shoshii.

sen.j: このため、平家一門が三位以上に列せられたのに続いて、当時、源氏の傍流となっていた摂津源氏の源頼政が、源氏として初めて従三位に昇った際には、異例とされ、世に源三位（げんざんみ）と称された。
sen.e: Thus, when MINAMOTO no Yorimasa of Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan), who had become a tributary of the Minamoto clan at that time, became the first from the Minamoto clan to be promoted to Jusanmi, after the Taira family were granted Sanmi and higher ranks, it was considered exceptional and was referred to as Genzanmi.

Thus, when MINAMOTO no Yorimasa of Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan), who had become a tributary of the Minamoto clan at that time, became the first from the Minamoto clan to be promoted to Jusanmi, after the Taira family were granted Sanmi and higher ranks, it was considered exceptional and was referred to as Genzanmi.

Thus, when MINAMOTO no Yorimasa of Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan), who had become a tributary of the Minamoto clan at that time, became the first from the Minamoto clan to be promoted to Jusanmi, after the Taira family were granted Sanmi and higher ranks, it was considered exceptional and was referred to as Genzanmi.

sen.j: 室町時代以降、従三位は歴代の足利将軍家連枝や鎌倉公方が叙せられた他、管領の斯波氏では斯波義重、斯波義敏が叙せられた。
sen.e: Since the Muromachi period, Jusanmi was granted to successive siblings of the Ashikaga Shogunate and Kamakura kubo (shogunate), and to Yoshishige SHIBA and Yoshitoshi SHIBA of the kanrei (deputy to shogun), Shiba clan,

Since the Muromachi period, Jusanmi was granted to successive siblings of the Ashikaga Shogunate and Kamakura kubo (shogunate), and to Yoshishige SHIBA and Yoshitoshi SHIBA of the kanrei (deputy to shogun), Shiba clan,

From the Muromachi period onward, the rank of Jusanmi was granted to successive generations of members of the Ashikaga Shogunate and the Kamakura Shogunate, as well as to Yoshishige SHIBA and Yoshitoshi SHIBA of the Shiba clan, members of whom held the position of kanrei (deputy to shogun).
sen.cmt: 連枝はsiblingsの意ゆえ、successiveは削除しました最後の行を書き換えました。The problem is not with the word "successive" but with the word "siblings", I think. The connection between "Shiba clan" and "kanrei" would have been unclear to the reader so I have revised other parts of the text too.

sen.j: また、管領として幕政を支えた畠山持国も従三位に昇っており有力な足利一門に叙位の例がみられる。
sen.e: Additionally, Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA who supported the shogunate as kanrei was also promoted to Jusanmi, and there are cases of the rank being granted to powerful members of the Ashikaga family.
Additionally, Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA who supported the shogunate as kanrei was also promoted to Jusanmi, and there are cases of the rank being granted to powerful members of the Ashikaga family.
Additionally, Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA who supported the shogunate as kanrei was also promoted to Jusanmi, and there are cases of the rank being granted to powerful members of the Ashikaga family.

sen.j: その他、室町時代後期には有力守護の赤松政則が叙せられるなど次第に足利氏以外の有力大名の叙位も見られるようになった。
sen.e: Furthermore, in the late Muromachi period, Masanori AKAMATSU, a powerful shugo (guardian), was granted the rank, and gradually, dominant daimyo (feudal lord) other than the Ashikaga clan began to be granted the rank.

Furthermore, in the late Muromachi period, Masanori AKAMATSU, a powerful shugo (guardian), was granted the rank, and gradually, dominant daimyo (feudal lord) other than the Ashikaga clan began to be granted the rank.

Furthermore, in the late Muromachi period, Masanori AKAMATSU, a powerful Shugo (provincial constable), was granted the rank, and gradually, dominant daimyo (feudal lord) other than the Ashikaga clan began to be granted the rank.

sen.j: 特に戦国時代初頭から中期にかけての叙位任官の事例をみると管領代として隆盛を誇った大内義興、若狭国の武田元信、日向国の伊東義祐も叙せられ叙位の例が見える。
sen.e: In particular, appointment of the rank from the beginning to the middle of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) includes Yoshioki OUCHI who prospered as kanreidai (deputy kanrei), Motonobu TAKEDA of Wakasa Province, and Yoshisuke ITO of Hyuga Province.

In particular, appointment of the rank from the beginning to the middle of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) includes Yoshioki OUCHI who prospered as kanreidai (deputy kanrei), Motonobu TAKEDA of Wakasa Province, and Yoshisuke ITO of Hyuga Province.

In particular, appointment of the rank from the beginning to the middle of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) includes Yoshioki OUCHI who prospered as kanreidai (deputy kanrei), Motonobu TAKEDA of Wakasa Province, and Yoshisuke ITO of Hyuga Province.

sen.j: 天下人とその一門以外の大名においては、事実上、この従三位が最高位となったが、大内義隆は従三位を経て、従二位まで昇叙するなど、時代を経るにつれ従三位を越える例も増えた。
sen.e: Among daimyo other than the ones who conquered the country and their families, Jusanmi was the highest rank, but Yoshitaka OUCHI was promoted from Jusanmi to Junii, and with time, there were more cases going beyond Jusanmi.

Among daimyo other than the ones who conquered the country and their families, Jusanmi was the highest rank, but Yoshitaka OUCHI was promoted from Jusanmi to Junii, and with time, there were more cases going beyond Jusanmi.

Among daimyo other than tenkabito (person becoming the ruler of the country) and their families, Jusanmi was the highest rank, but Yoshitaka OUCHI was promoted from Jusanmi to Junii (Junior Second Rank), and with time, there were more cases going beyond Jusanmi.
sen.cmt: 天下人の訳を補足従二位の説明補足

sen.j: 後に右大臣に昇る織田信長の一時期この位にあり、その嫡男 織田信忠は従三位左近衛中将の位にあった。
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA, who later becomes Udaijin also at one time held this rank, and his eldest son Nobutada ODA's rank was Jusanmi Sakonoe-Chujo (assistant director of the left of the inner palace guard division).
sen.cmt: 「織田信長の」は「織田信長も」と解釈しました。
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA, who later becomes Udaijin also at one time held this rank, and his eldest son Nobutada ODA's rank was Jusanmi Sakonoe-Chujo (assistant director of the left of the inner palace guard division).

Nobunaga ODA, who later becomes Udaijin also at one time held this rank, and his eldest son Nobutada ODA's rank was Jusanmi Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 左近衛中将の訳を補足

sen.j: 武家初の関白となった豊臣秀吉が天下統一を果たして以降は、武家が高位に昇る例が増え一門や上杉景勝、毛利輝元などの大名に三位が与えられた。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who became the first Kanpaku (advisor to the Emperor) from a samurai family, conquered the country, samurai were increasingly promoted to high ranks, and Sanmi was granted to the clan and daimyo such as Kagemasa UESUGI and Terumoto MORI.

After Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who became the first Kanpaku (advisor to the Emperor) from a samurai family, conquered the country, samurai were increasingly promoted to high ranks, and Sanmi was granted to the clan and daimyo such as Kagemasa UESUGI and Terumoto MORI.

After Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who became the first Kanpaku (chief advisor to the Emperor) from a samurai family, conquered the country, samurai were increasingly promoted to high ranks, and Sanmi was granted to the clan and daimyo such as Kagemasa UESUGI and Terumoto MORI.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の下では、征夷大将軍の嫡孫、徳川御三家、御三卿、将軍の息女を正室とした加賀藩の藩主などが叙せられた。
sen.e: Under the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), the inheriting grandson of the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), the Tokugawa gosanke (three families of the Tokugawas), the gosankyo (three Tokugawa clan families who separated from the clan), and the lord of Kaga Domain who wedded the daughter of the Shogun were granted the rank.

Under the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), the inheriting grandson of the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), the Tokugawa gosanke (three families of the Tokugawas), the gosankyo (three Tokugawa clan families who separated from the clan), and the lord of Kaga Domain who wedded the daughter of the Shogun were granted the rank.

Under the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), the inheriting grandson of the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of Tokugawa family), the gosankyo (three Tokugawa clan families who separated from the clan), and the lord of Kaga Domain who wedded the daughter of the Shogun were granted the rank.
sen.cmt: 徳川御三家の訳を補足

sen.j: 近代以降、従三位は爵位のうち子爵に相当し、子爵の多い武家華族などの叙位例が顕著である。
sen.e: In modern days, Jusanmi corresponds to Shishaku (viscount) in shakui (court rank), and ranks granted to bukekazoku (samurai families from the Edo period becoming nobles in the Meiji period) who had many Shishaku were notable.

In modern days, Jusanmi corresponds to Shishaku (viscount) in shakui (court rank), and ranks granted to bukekazoku (samurai families from the Edo period becoming nobles in the Meiji period) who had many Shishaku were notable.

In modern days, Jusanmi corresponds to Shishaku (viscount) in shakui (the rank of nobility), and ranks granted to bukekazoku (samurai families from the Edo period becoming nobles in the Meiji period) who had many Shishaku were notable.
sen.cmt: court rank→the rank of nobility [Webster's Online Dictionary]

sen.j: 軍人の階級では陸軍大将に相当した。
sen.e: In the ranks for military personnel, it corresponded to Army General.
In the ranks for military personnel, it corresponded to Army General.
In the ranks for military personnel, it corresponded to Army General.

sen.j: 今日では主に国会議員、都道府県知事経験者や学者などで勲二等の叙勲を受けた者と同等の功績を挙げた者が死後に叙位されることが一般的である。
sen.e: Today, it is commonly granted posthumously to persons who made similar achievements as former Diet members, prefectural governors, or scholars who received conferment of the Kunnito.
Today, it is commonly granted posthumously to persons who made similar achievements as former Diet members, prefectural governors, or scholars who received conferment of the Kunnito.

Today, it is commonly granted posthumously to persons who made similar achievements as former Diet members, prefectural governors, or scholars who received conferment of the Kunnito (Order of Second Class).
